subject: dbus_utility: Add getResourceName to convert dbus path to Resource name
commitMessage:
dbus_utility: Add getResourceName to convert dbus path to Resource name

Use the decoded dbus path as the ID and removed "_\d+" for the Name.

The Name will remove the number after the last `_` found in the decoded
name.

The use case is that it look at the Name to create the devpath
and that needs to be the same across different resources.

For example, we want
```
/PE0/cpld
/PE1/cpld
```

Instead of having

```
/PE0/cpld_0
/PE1/cpld_1
```

Reference Mockup: https://redfish.dmtf.org/redfish/mockups/v1/1101

Change-Id: I4384368c175b486a244bba05f02b803a3d467a91
Signed-off-by: Willy Tu <wltu@google.com>

nit, string_view is generally preferred today.

oh nice. We moved to cpp20.

Let me update it.
string_view was c++17, and we had boost::string_view long before that 😊

oh right. I think only like start_with was added to string_view in 20 and I was waiting for that in some project.

Nice

seems like it underflow and actually do the loop. But since the test didn't have the valid name to be all number, if didn't catch it.

Let me add that test case.

Yeah, looking from the back is probably easier. Thanks.

remove_suffix only affect the size.

Doing 
```
return id;
```

returns the full data.

it will fail in this case.

```
[ RUN      ] DbusUtility.getResourceName
../include/ut/dbus_utility_test.cpp:43: Failure
Expected equality of these values:
  dbus::utility::getResourceName("hello_world_1a23")
    Which is: "hello_world_1a"
  "hello_world_1a23"
[  FAILED  ] DbusUtility.getResourceName (0 ms)
[----------] 3 tests from DbusUtility (0 ms total)
```

---

I have refactored it to basically have another string_view  to of the id.
Ack

I see 

"Id":view details "Blade1",
"Name":view details "Blade",


but I still don't understand the purpose here..
In this mockup, they seem to remove the digits from the id but why do we need to?

Because if we have two of the same "thing" you need to be able to tell that they're the same via the Name.  Ie, Drive 1 and Drive 2 should both be of name "Drive" so that users can use Name to match up on the device type, and not have to rely on odata.id.

I also think that we should be prefixing all of these with OBMC or something similar (ie OBMC Drive) so that users can differentiate common terms like "drive" from their equivalents on say, an ilo system, but that's a much bigger change.

What is the point of the PrettyName interface https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/08baf48ad5f15774d393fbbf4e9479a0ef3e82d0/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item.interface.yaml#L5 if we going to do this? 

I think we need some documentation around this if this is the direction we are headed
maybe some context in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43967/41#message-0c9242a30e77998dce5fbed12dbef7b62046b903?

> What is the point of the PrettyName interface

The PrettyName interface was created before redfish, and doesn't have the same guarantees as the path name (it's essentially free form for any given index of device).  FWIW, given the way it's currently defined, it didn't really help with redfish, and we made the explicit decision not to use it long....long ago.  I'm happy to revisit that, but considering that this patch is just improving the status quo (ie fixing a bug/corner) I suspect it can go in ahead of any "use prettyname" patch.
anymore concern here?
friendly ping.
nit: return std::string{id};
Done
One thing I thought of about the above, how does this work for things that actually end with a number, for example "AgoraV2"?

that is the same case as

```
EXPECT_EQ(dbus::utility::getResourceName("hello_world_1a23"),
              "hello_world_1a23");
```

it will only accept `_{numbers}` and remove it. The number have to follow right after `_` for it to work. Otherwise, it will not do anything.
Ah, fair point.
Done
ping
I added a comment in the child patch to ask why we need to remove suffix from names.

We want a way to set any name to the resource.

Since ID is already the dbus path with the suffix, we are using without the suffix as the name to group them together. If it is not removed, then it will just be the same as ID.

> we are using without the suffix as the name to group them together

Why do we want to group?

And also does this imply a certain pattern for the object path in the daemon is required?

It doesn't have to group anything. I just meant that if we are searching for like a resource all SSD_X, we can find it directly.

The use case is that it look at the Name to create the devpath and that needs to be the same across different resources. For example,

```
/PE0/cpld
/PE1/cpld
```

Instead of having

```
/PE0/cpld_0
/PE1/cpld_1
```

The flexibility allow us to create the first set of names. I guess it does require the object path to have suffix of `_index` if we want to use it. That's already being done with FriDevice and EntityManager for the most part. If not, it will not affect it.

Thanks, 

```
The use case is that it look at the Name to create the devpath and that needs to be the same across different resources. For example,
/PE0/cpld
/PE1/cpld
Instead of having
/PE0/cpld_0
/PE1/cpld_1
```

Consider adding this into the commit message? That's exactly what I was asking for.

>  I guess it does require the object path to have suffix of `_index` if we want to use it

Not only the _index suffix, but also the inventory type, right. The format must be 

```
${inventoryType}_${index}
```

`${inventoryType}` can be anything that people want. I don't think there's any required in that. The Name could be anything people want it to be.

The Name doesn't have to be the inventoryType, right?
Wait, I thought in our case, the name has to be `cpld_${index}`
yeah, I think that's just for Google's internal requirements. Should be flexible for everyone else.
this just checks non empty?
yeah, pretty much. I'll clean it up and test it out again.
TestCaseName should be PascalCase.
Done

I just realized the unit test clean up was merged. Then I would suggest we use even better suite and test case names. 

TEST(GetResourceName, NumericSuffixRemoved)

TEST(GetResourceName, OtherSuffixNotRemoved)
Done
